data: If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 9 steps left. Take 10 steps forward. Take 9 steps right. Take 10 steps backward. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
On a standard scale, the length of a stair is 60 metres. So, the answer is Yes.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 4 steps. Turn around. Take 4 steps. Turn around. Turn right. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
If you take 4 steps and turn around, you eventually turn around and turn right. So, the answer is yes.

The first steps are where you start to walk. You should not return to where you started unless you are already there. So, the answer is No.

Your starting point is the same as your destination, with 10 steps taken. So, the answer is Yes.

You take 10 steps to return to the starting point. You take 9 steps to return to the starting point. So, the answer is Yes.

Turn around and take 7 steps at each of the 7 direction changes. When you are back to the original direction turn around and take 7 steps at each of the 7 directions. So, the answer is yes.

Whenever you want to get back on track, there are 2 steps in front of you. When you take 2 steps, you are doing it 2 times. So, the answer is Yes.

If you always face forward, it is obvious that you will always go forward. In the example, you would take 6 steps forward which is six a second. So, the answer is Yes.

You can never return to your starting point if you are already there. So, the answer is yes.

If you face forward you always take step forward. If you face backwards, you take step backward. If you face forward you always walk forward. So, the answer is No.

This is the same as the way people typically walk, though the directions are different. So, the answer is No.

The first instruction tells you to get closer towards the starting point. The fourth instruction tells you to get farther away from the starting point. Take your initial steps forward. You’ ll have taken three steps right and one step backward. Take one step forward. You’ ll have taken one step backward. Take 6 steps left. You’ ll have taken one step forward. Take three steps right. Thus, the answer is Yes.

Take 5 steps if you are going towards the starting point. Take 2 steps if you are going to return to the starting point. Take 5 and 3 steps together to get to the starting point. Take 2 and 3 steps together to get to the starting point. Take 3 and 2 steps together to get to the starting point. Take 10 steps when you are going to return to the starting point. So, the answer is Yes.

It takes 3 steps + 7 steps + 1 step to make the same step back to the starting point as the previous step. So, the answer is Yes.

This sequence of steps is repeated 5 times backwards, and back 7 times forwards. The starting point is always face forward. Thus, the answer is Yes.

The first step towards starting takes 6 steps forward. There are 4 steps forward, then 5 steps forward, then a further 4 steps forward, and then 4 steps forward again. The first step to getting to the starting point is to take 6 steps forward. Thus, the answer is Yes.

If you follow a series, you take more than one sequence repeating the order in which you start. If you know you are taking 5 steps, then take 5 steps when you move from your feet to your torso. Whenever a person is facing forward and facing forward, their back is always facing forward and they always start from the same place. When facing backward and forward, they always begin forward. If they always start at the same place, then they would never face forward and be at the original point. So, the answer is Yes.
